The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

Together with a Confutation of ≈øome Reports of a fained Miracle upon the fore≈øaid Petition, being thrown over-board at Sea; As al≈øo a breif An≈øwer to ≈øome pa≈ø≈øages in a late Book (entituled Hypocri≈øie unmasked) ≈øet out by Mr. Win≈ølowe, concerning the Independent Churches holding communion with the Reformed Churches.

div.head: The Preface.
div.p: THE occa≈øion of Printing this following Relation, are the ≈øufferings that not only my Brother Robert Child Doctor of Phy≈øick, with ≈øome Gentlemen and others have ≈øuffered in New-England in their per≈øons and e≈øtates by Fines and impri≈øonments there, but here in England in their repute by fal≈øe reports and fained Miracles invented and ≈øpread on purpo≈øe by ≈øome lately come from thence, and fomented by ≈øome others here to colour their unju≈øt proceedings.
Fir≈øt, they give out of my Brother and others, that they de≈øire a Toleration of all Religions.
Secondly, that they are trouble≈øome per≈øons, and again≈øt all government both in Church and Commonwealth.
Thirdly, that ≈øome of them are come from thence to Petition the Parliament for that purpo≈øe.

4ly, that their Petition brought from thence to be pre≈øented to the Parliam. (which they had named Jonas) in a
Ship called the Supply, being in a ≈øtorme neer Silly, out of horror of con≈øcience, the Petition was come and thrown over board, and that then the ≈øtorm immediatly cea≈øed, and they miraculou≈øly ≈øaved.
Now for ≈øatisfaction, I pre≈øent to the Reader the≈øe following particulars.
Fir≈øt, the Petition of the greater part of the Inhabitants of Hingham and the proceedings therein.
Secondly, a Petition of Doctor Child and others delivered to the generall Court at Bo≈øton with ≈øome pa≈ø≈øages thereupon,
Thirdly, the Capital Laws of the Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øets Bay, with the Free-mans Oath as they are printed there by them≈øelves.
Fourthly, a Relation of that ≈øtory of Jonas verbatim, as it was delivered to me in writing by a Gentleman that was then a pa≈ø≈øenger in the Ship.

div.head: The Petition of the greater part of the Inhabitants of Hingham, as it was taken out of the Records of the Court at Bo≈øton.

To the Honoured, the Generall Court, con≈øi≈øting of the Magi≈øtrates and Deputies of the Country now a≈ø≈øembled in Court at Bo≈øton: The humble Petition of the greater part of the Inhabitants of the Town≈øhip of Hingham.
div.p:
WHereas there hath fallen out ≈øome agitations among≈øt us concerning the choice of our chief Military Officers, which by Order of the Court we have power to choo≈øe (as we conceive) So it is that we did elect, and pre≈øent to the Generall Court for their confirmation, Mr. Bozoune Allin for our Chieftain: but the Court not having time to fini≈øh that bu≈øines at that time, ≈øome other things and overtures have happened ≈øince, whereby it hath ≈øo fallen out that ≈øome of us have been compelled to appeare before ≈øome of the Magi≈øtrates, and to give Bonds for appearance at a Quarter-Court which is to be holden after this Generall Court; and ≈øome for not giving Bond to an≈øwer there, are committed to pri≈øon, and remain there at pre≈øent; the matters of accu≈øation (as we conceive) is for certain words ≈øpoken by ≈øome, concerning the liberty and power of the Generall Court, and our own liberty granted to us by the ≈øaid Courts, and to the Country in generall; and al≈øo it doth concern the Liberty of an Engli≈øh free-borne Member of that State, and further it hath occa≈øioned ≈øuch di≈øturbance and ≈øchi≈øme in our Church, and trouble to ≈øome of our Members for witne≈ø≈øing again≈øt a Delinquent: whereby the power of the Ordinances of Je≈øus Chri≈øt in his Church is ≈ølighted, and the free pa≈ø≈øage thereof ≈øtopped, to the endangering of the liberty of the Churches among≈øt
us, if timely remedy be not by your Wi≈ødoms provided. Now ≈øeeing the matters in hand doth concern the generall liberty of the whole Couuntry, and the peace of the Churches, and glory of God, as we are ready upon the hearing of the Court to make it appeare; We humbly ≈øue to this honoured Court to be plea≈øed to grant us an honourable and free hearing, and that we may have liberty to plead our common Liberties in this Court, together with the liberties of the Churches of Chri≈øt maintained. And we ≈øhall ever pray for your peace and pro≈øperity long to continue.

For which Petition being fined 100. l. and the Mar≈øhal ≈øent to Hingham to levy the ≈øaid Fine: Mr. Hubbard the Mini≈øter of that town being one of them that was fined, the Mar≈øhal coming to his hou≈øe to levy part thereof, produced this effect as followeth taken out of their Records.

div.head: THE RELATION.
div.p:
THe 18. of the fir≈øt Moneth, 1645. the Mar≈øhall going to gather 100. l. in Fines of divers Inhabitants of Hingham, as they were ≈øet by the Generall Court, in the 3. or 4. moneth pa≈øt; came to Mr. Peter Hubbard, who de≈øiring to ≈øee his Warrant, which the Mar≈øhall ≈øhewing him, upon a ≈øight of it Mr. Hubbard ≈øaid the Warrant was in≈øufficient, being not ≈øent out in his Maje≈øties name, he being ≈øworne to the Crown of England; and ≈øaid that they had ≈øent into England unto his Friends the bu≈øines, and expected ≈øhortly an an≈øwer and advice from thence: And that our Government here was not more then a Corporation in England, and that we had not power to put men to death by vertue of the Patent, nor to do ≈øome other things we did; and that for him≈øelf, he had neither horn nor hoo≈øe of his own, nor any thing wherewith to buy his children cloaths, And he wi≈øhed that the Magi≈øtrates would take ≈øome cour≈øe that the Mini≈øters might be better provided for, and he wondered by what order or rule the Mini≈øters were deprived of their Tythes: but if he mu≈øt pay it, he would pay it in Books, but that he knew not for
what they were fined, unle≈ø≈øe it were for Petitioning; and if they were ≈øo wa≈øpi≈øh they might not be Petitioned, then he could not tell what to ≈øay, (about thirty or forty being pre≈øent.) And further, that he had ≈øeriou≈øly con≈øidered what they had done, and he could not ≈øee any thing they had done ami≈ø≈øe, for which they ≈øhould be Fined.

div.head: The Returne of this Jury.
div.p: WE do find, that Mr. Peter Hubbard of Hingham, being a Free-man of this Juri≈ødiction, and having taken the Oath of fidelity thereunto: ≈øeeming notwith≈øtanding to be evil-affected to the Government here e≈øtabli≈øhed; In and upon the 18. day of the fir≈øt Moneth la≈øt pa≈øt, at Hingham afore≈øaid, in the pre≈øence of about thirty per≈øons, did utter divers ≈øpeeches which are upon record, tending to ≈øedition and contempt of the ≈øaid Government, contrary to the law of God, and peace and welfare of the Country.

Upon which Return of the Jury, the Court fined him Twenty pounds, and bound him in Forty pounds to be of good behaviour and to appeare at next Quarter-Court; and Mr. Peck bound him≈øelf in twenty pounds, for the good behaviour and appearance of Mr. Peter Hubbard at the next Quarter-Court.

head.hi: The Remon≈øtrance and humble Petition of us who≈øe Names are here under-written, in the behalf of our ≈øelves and divers within this Juri≈ødiction.

div.p: HUmbly ≈øhoweth, That we cannot but with all thankfulne≈ø≈øe acknowledge your indefatigable pains, continuall care, and con≈øtant vigilancie, which (by the ble≈ø≈øing of the Almighty) hath procured unto this Wilderne≈ø≈øe the much de≈øired fruits of Peace and Plenty; while our native Land, ye ‚Ä¢ the Chri≈øtian world is ≈øharply afflicted with the devouring Sword, and the ≈øad con≈øequents of Inte≈øtine wars. And further, That you whom the Lord hath placed at the helm of the≈øe Plantations, and endowed with eminent gifts fit for ≈øuch honourable callings, are be≈øt able to fore≈øee the clouds which hang over our heads, the „Äà‚óä„Äâ and tempe≈øts which threaten this poor Handfull here planted; and timou≈øly to amend them. Notwith≈øtanding, tho≈øe who are under „Äà‚óä„Äâ , being at pre≈øent unfit for higher imployments, may perceive tho≈øe Leaks which will inevitably ≈øink this weak and ill compacted Ve≈ø≈øell, if not by your Wi≈ødoms opportunely prevented.

We therefore in the behalf of our ≈øelves and divers of our Countrymen, laying our hands on our brea≈øts, and ≈øeriou≈øly con≈øidering, That the hand of our good God who through his goodne≈ø≈øe hath ≈øafely brought us and ours through the great Ocean, and planted us here, ≈øeems not now to be with us, nay rather again≈øt us, bla≈øting all our de≈øigns, though contrived with much deliberation, undertaken with great care, and proceeding with more then ordinary probability of ≈øuccesfull events; by which many of good e≈øtates are brought to the brinks of extreme poverty; yea, at this time laying His ju≈øt hand upon our families, taking many away to him≈øelf, ≈øtriking others with unwonted malignant ≈øickne≈ø≈øes and noy≈øome ≈øhamefull di≈øea≈øes: Have thought it convenient, with all re≈øpectivene≈ø≈øe, to pre≈øent the≈øe our ≈øincere reque≈øts and Remon≈øtrance to this honoured Court, hoping we have found out the ≈øpeciall Leaks, which concurring with the many and great Sins of this place, (which our Con≈øciences know, and our Brethren of England are not ignorant of) are the ≈øpeciall cau≈øes of the Lords turning his face from us, leaving us to our ≈øelves, and con≈øequently to ≈øtrife, contention, unfaithfulne≈ø≈øe, idlene≈ø≈øe, and other lamentable failings, not ble≈ø≈øing us in any of our endeavours, ≈øo as to give us any great hopes of Staple-commodities, and con≈øequently of comfortable ≈øub≈øi≈øtence; though we to the utmo≈øt of our powers the≈øe many years, even to the exhau≈øting of our e≈øtates and ≈øpirits, have endeavoured the ≈øame: but contrariwi≈øe all things grow wor≈øe and wor≈øe, even to the threatning (in our apprehen≈øions) of no le≈ø≈øe then finall ruine. Not doubting but you will receive the≈øe our Reque≈øts and Remon≈øtrance with the ≈øame candor of mind, which we, not aiming at novelty and di≈øturbance but at the glory of God, our allegiance to the State of England, and good of the≈øe poor Plantations, (if our hearts deceive us not) pre≈øent them unto you; though for want of skill and other nece≈ø≈øary helps roughly drawn up; and hope that you will be more diligent in an ending then we in the ≈øearching out the cau≈øes of the≈øe our pre≈øent calamities, „Äà‚óä„Äâ Not to trouble you (who are imployed in the mo≈øt ≈øerious affaires of the≈øe Plantations) with many wor ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , wee ≈øhall briefly referre them to tho≈øe Heads‚Äî

1. Whereas this place hath been planted by the incouragements (next under God) of Letters Patents given and granted by His Maje≈øty of England to the Inhabitants hereof, with many priviledges and immunities, viz. Incorporation into a Company, liberty of choo≈øing Governours, ≈øetling Government, making Laws not repugnant to the Laws of England, power of admini≈øtring the Oath of Allegiance to all, &c. as by the ≈øaid Letters Patents more largely appeareth. Notwith≈øtanding we cannot according to our judgements cleerly di≈øcern a ≈øetled form of Government according to the Fundamentall lawes of England; which may ≈øeem ≈øtrange to our Country-men, yea to the whole World, e≈øpecially con≈øidering we are all Engli≈øh. Neither do we ≈øo under≈øtand or perceive our own Lawes or Liberties, or any Body of Lawes here ≈øo e≈øtabli≈øhed, as that thereby there may be a ≈øure and comfortable enjoyment of our Lives, Liberties and E≈øtates, according to our due Naturall rights, as Free-born ≈øubjects of the Engli≈øh nation. By which many inconveniences flow into the≈øe Plantations, viz. Jealou≈øies of introducing Arbitrary Government, (which many are prone to believe) con≈øtruing the procra≈øtination of ≈øuch ≈øetled Lawes, to proceed from an overgreedy ≈øpirit of Arbitrary power (which it may be is their weakne≈ø≈øe) ≈øuch proceedings being mo≈øt dete≈øtable to our Engli≈øh Nation, and to all good men, and at pre≈øent a chief cau≈øe of the inte≈øtine War in our dear Country. Further it gives cau≈øe to many, to think them≈øelves hardly dealt with, others too much favoured, and the ≈øcale of Ju≈øtice too much bowed and unequally ballanced: From whence al≈øo proceedeth feares and jealou≈øies of illegall Commitments, unju≈øt Impri≈øonments, Taxes, Rates, Cu≈øtomes, Levies, of ungrounded and undoing A≈ø≈øe≈øments, unju≈øtifiable Pre≈ø≈øes, undue Fines, unmea≈øurable Expences and Charges, of unconceivable dangers through a Negative or de≈øtructive Vote unduly placed, or not well regulated; in a word, of a Non-certainty of all things we enjoy, whether lives, liberties or e≈øtates; as al≈øo of undue Oaths, being ≈øubject to expo≈øition according to the will of him or them that gives them, and not according to a due and unbowed rule of Law, which is the true Interpreter of all Oaths to all men, whether Judge, on Judged.

Wherefore our humble de≈øire and reque≈øti ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . That you would be plea≈øed to con≈øider of our pre≈øent condition, and upon what foundation we ≈øtand; and unanimou≈øly concurre to e≈øtabli≈øh the Fundamentall and whol≈øome Lawes of our native Country, and ≈øuch others as are no way repugnant to them, unto which all of us are mo≈øt accu≈øtomed, and we ≈øuppo≈øe them be≈øt agreeable to our Engli≈øh tempers, and your ≈øelves obliged thereunto by the Generall Charter, and your Oaths of Allegiance: neither can we tell whether the Lord hath ble≈øt many in the≈øe Parts with ≈øuch eminent Politicall gifts, ≈øo as to contrive better Lawes and Cu≈øtomes, than the Wi≈øe≈øt of our Nation have with great con≈øideration compo≈øed, and by many hundred years experience have found mo≈øt equall and ju≈øt; which have procured to the Nation much honour and renown among≈øt ≈øtrangers, and long peace and tranquility among≈øt them≈øelves. And for the more ≈øtrict and due ob≈øervation and execution of the ≈øaid Lawes by all Mini≈øters of Ju≈øtice, that there may be a ≈øetled Rule for them to walk by in ca≈øes of Judicature, from which if they ≈øwerve, there may be ≈øome Power ≈øetled, according to the Lawes of England, that may call them to account for their Delinquencie, which may be a good means to prevent divers unnece≈ø≈øary Appeals into England.

2. Whereas there are many thou≈øands in the≈øe Plantations of the Engli≈øh Nation free-born, quiet peaceable men, righteous in their dealings forward with hand, heart and pur≈øe to advance the publike good, known friends to the honourable and victorious Hou≈øes of Parliament, lovers of the Nation, &c. Who are debarred from all Civil imployment (without any ju≈øt cau≈øe that we know) not being permitted to beare the lea≈øt office (though it cannot be denied but ≈øome are well qualified) No not ≈øo much as to have any Vote in choo≈øing Magi≈øtrates, Captains, or other Civil or Military Officers; notwith≈øtanding they have here expended their youth, born the burthen of the day, wa≈øted much of their e≈øtates for the ≈øub≈øi≈øtence of the≈øe poor Plantations, paid all a≈ø≈øe≈øments taxes, rates, at lea≈øt equal, if not exceeding others: Yea, when the late War was denounced again≈øt the Naragau≈øet Indians, without their con≈øent; their goods were ≈øei≈øed on for the ≈øervice, them≈øelves and ≈øervants e≈øpecially forced and impre≈øt
to ≈øerve in that was, to the hazarding of the things mo≈øt neer and dear unto them. Whence i≈ø≈øue forth many great inconveniences, ≈øecret di≈øcontents, murmurings, rents in the Plantations, di≈øcouragements in their callings, un≈øetledne≈ø≈øe of minde, ≈øtrife, contention, (and the Lord only knows to what a name in time it may kindle) al≈øo jealou≈øies of too much unwarranted power and dominion on the one ≈øide, and of perpetuall ≈ølavery and bondage to them and their po≈øterity on the other, and which is intolerable, even by them who ought to love and re≈øpect them as brethren, &c.

We therefore de≈øire, that Civil liberty and freedome be forthwith granted to all truly Engli≈øh, equall to the re≈øt of their Country-men, as in all Plantations is accu≈øtomed to be done, and as all Free-borne enjoy in our native Country; we hoping here in ≈øome things to enjoy greater liberties then el≈øwhere, counting it no ≈ømall lo≈ø≈øe of liberty to be as it were bani≈øhed from our native home, and enforced to lay our bones in a ≈øtrange wilderne≈ø≈øe. Without impo≈øing any Oaths or Covenants on them, which we ≈øuppo≈øe cannot be warranted by the Letters Patents, and ≈øeem not to concurre with the Oath of Allegiance formerly enforced on all, and later Covenants lately impo≈øed on many here pre≈øent by the honourable Hou≈øes of Parliament; or at lea≈øt to detract from our native Country, and Laws, (which by ≈øome are ≈øtiled Foraign, and this Place termed rather a Free State, then a Colony or Corporation of England) All of us being very willing to take ≈øuch Oaths and Covenants; as are expre≈ø≈øions of our de≈øires of advancing the glory of God and good of this place, of our duties to the State of England and love to our Nation, being compo≈øed according to the laws and cu≈øtomes of other Corporations of England. But all of us are exceedingly unwilling, by any policies what≈øoever, to be rent from our Native country, though far di≈øtant from it; valuing our free Denizations, the Immunities and Priviledges which we and our po≈øterity do, and we hope ≈øhall alwayes enjoy, above the greate≈øt Honours of this Country not cemented to the State of England; and glory to be accounted though but as Ru≈øhes of that Land, and yet that we may to „Äà‚óä„Äâ to write, that we and ours are Engli≈øh. Or at lea≈øt we intreat, that the Bodies of us and
ours (Engli≈øh ≈øubjects po≈ø≈øe≈øing here no priviledges) may not be impre≈øt, nor Goods forcibly taken away; le≈øt we not knowing the ju≈øtne≈ø≈øe of the war, may be ignorantly and unwillingly inforced upon our own de≈øtructions. And that all A≈ø≈øe≈øments, Taxes, Impo≈øitions, (which are many and grievous) if Civil liberty be not granted) may be taken off, that in all things we may be Strangers: otherwi≈øe we ≈øuppo≈øe our ≈øelves in a wor≈øe ca≈øe here, and le≈ø≈øe free, then, the Natives among≈øt whom we live, or any Aliens. div.head: POST-SCRIPT.
div.p:
THere is a book lately ≈øet-forth by Mr. Edward Win≈ølow of New England, again≈øt Samuel Gorton, intituled [Hypocri≈øie unmasked] in which there is a deep and ≈øubtle Plot again≈øt the Lawes of England, and Liberties of Engli≈øh Subjects, and the Gentlemen that are now ≈øuffering in New-England. This man being a principall oppo≈øer of the Lawes of England, in New-England; One who is u≈øually in place of Government in New-Plimouth there. Now in N. England there are many ≈øeveral Governments di≈øtinct and independent one from and on the other, and none of them have, ever ≈øince they came into that Country, governed by the Lawes of England, but by an Arbitrary government of their own, nor indeed can they endure the Laws of Eng. the Parliament here, to maintain what they have begun, & made ≈øo great a progre≈ø≈øe in. They have made a Law, that it ≈øhall be death for any there to attempt the alteration and ≈øubver≈øion of their Frame of Polity or Government, as it is apparent by tho≈øe Lawes in Print ≈øet forth by them≈øelves, the Copy whereof is in pag 16. of this Book ≈øet forth; and al≈øo proceeded to the Fining and Impri≈øoning of ≈øome well-affected Engli≈øh, whom they fear will complain of this their Arbitrary government, that ≈øo none may dare to ≈øeek for a remedy from the Parliament. In his Epi≈øtle before the book which he dedicates to the Honourable Commi≈ø≈øioners for Forraign Plantations, he makes five Reque≈øts to them, the fourth of which is, That they will take into con≈øideration, how de≈øtructive it will be to their Plantations, and proceedings there, (which ≈øaith he are growing into a Nation) to an≈øwer to complaints here. See and ob≈øerve (Reader) how he ≈øeeks to ≈øtop all Appeals from all their unju≈øt Sentences, what≈øoever they may be contrary to the Lawes of England. Secondly, he would make their Honours to be the In≈øtruments to ≈øtop the Currant of the greate≈øt Liberty of Engli≈øh ≈øubjects there; he would engage the Parliament in it; and what a de≈øperate bu≈øine≈ø≈øe this would prove, every wi≈øe man may ea≈øily ≈øee: For being begun at this Plantation, by the ≈øame rule others might ≈øeek it ≈øhould extend to all other Plantations, and then why not to Ireland? and why ≈øhall not example, cu≈øtome, and fair pretences bring it into Wales and Cornwal, ≈øo over England? And by the way (Reader) mark his great boa≈øting that they are growing into a Nation; high concel ‚Ä¢ s of a Nation breeds high thoughts of them≈øelves; which makes them u≈øually term them≈øelves a State, cal the people there Subjects,
